There is now provision for there to be mobile booths as part of the voting system within those hospitals to the extent that that has not been the case already. Proposed new section 113C is to deal with the situations of those hospitals which hitherto have not been routinely established as polling places and to make provision for their getting the special facility of mobile booths, with the option of the five-day period and so on that goes with it. So the smaller nursing homes and so on that until now have not had the facility of a full scale polling booth being established there will be able to share in the convenience of the mobile booth system. Does that answer the honourable senator' s question?
—Yes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendment which the Opposition was proposing, amendment No. (11) circulated in our name, is in fact consequential upon a matter which has been resolved earlier. Section 116 of the principal Act requires that the words 'or occupation' remain. So the previous matter having been disposed of, we do not intend to proceed with that amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause agreed to.
Clauses 91 to 97-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 98 (Marking of votes in a Senate election).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (12) Page 117, paragraph 98 (b), proposed new sub-section 123 (1B), lines 33 to 36, leave out the proposed sub-section.

This amendment seeks to leave out proposed new section 123 (1B), lines 33 to 36 on page 117. This clause introduces a new method of recording a vote by the use of a tick or a cross as opposed to writing a number. It is perhaps the first step down the road which could, in the end, take one to first past the post voting. One of our objections to what is proposed is that it suggests that for the Senate one can use a tick or a cross; for the House of Representatives we understand that numbers will still be required. We would not disagree with the aim of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform to reduce informality in voting. The argument here is an argument only as to the methods people will use.

The words to which we are objecting which we are proposing should be omitted are words which permit the use of a tick or a cross rather than a number. We do not believe that a valid case has been made for using a tick or a cross; that is the first think. We believe that this will require electors when they vote to follow two different sets of criteria: A set for the paper they will have for the House of Representatives and a different set for the Senate where they will be able to put a tick or a cross. If it is the will of the Parliament that they should be able to vote for a list-we are opposed to that-we think they should do it by number. They should use a number on all occasions. We believe that the way to reduce informal voting is to give people some consistency in what they do. We do not believe that using that kind of mark will help electors in the long run. While we applaud the idea or reducing informality in voting, we do not think this is an appropriate way to go. The Opposition asks the Committee to support the amendment which I have moved.

TALK.START.PARA: — There is a problem here. I understand the point that has been made by Senator Baume, but when people see a box they tend to tick it or cross it. That is a fact of life. Unfortunately, no amount of proposals would influence them to put a number in the box unless other numbers are there to follow.
—Sometimes ticks and crosses mean the same thing.
—Exactly. As a matter of fact, in some union elections there is provision for the voting to take place by a cross.
—For 83 years we have been putting numbers.

—Yes, but when people put numbers they do so because they are signifying a first preference and then subsequent preferences, such as, '2, 3, 4 , 5, 6', et cetera. I agree, however, with Senator Baume that it would be unfortunate if this were the first step along the road to first past the post voting. I wonder whether his point could be catered for by our inserting somewhere in the Act-I disagree with regulations being made about electoral matters-a prohibition which would prevent candidates from urging electors to mark their list box with a tick or a cross.
—I have an amendment on that. I have an amendment which will do that.
—I am sorry; I have not seen that. That answers the question.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I simply congratulate Senator Peter Baume on spinning out for nearly a minute what was so manifestly an implausible argument. If he is serious about reducing informal voting he ought to accept the provision that where an intention is as clearly demonstrated as it would be by the insertion of a tick or a cross in a box it ought to be registered as formal. Slippery slopes and floodgate sorts of arguments are never persuasive at the best of times and they are manifestly very unpersuasive in the context of this amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the honourable senator's claim that we are one foot down the path towards first past the post voting, I simply draw his attention to the language of the clause which states the requirement in terms of placing a figure one on the ballot paper. Consistent with that, electoral advertising, instructions to voters and so on would have to continue to be expressed in terms of an obligation of that kind. All that the clause does is make it clear that when someone nonetheless uses a tick or a cross instead of a figure one that vote will not be deemed to be invalid for that reason. That will be further reinforced by the amendment that Senator Macklin will propose in a moment I think to clause 103. With those various safeguards such shred of credibility as Senator Baume's argument had falls away. The Government urges that the clause stay in the form in which it appears in the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think the note of asperity that the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) has brought into this argument is justified. I think there is a danger here of confusion, of coming to wrong conclusions if the tick and the cross are accepted. The Attorney-General says that a tick or a cross will demonstrate a voter's intention. It may well not do so. An elector who, for example, dislikes intensely the Communist Party may well place a cross in the relevant box to indicate that he does not want that Party to be elected. That may be confusing and he would thereby be found to be voting for the Communist Party.
—He would put a tick in another box and therefore render the whole thing informal.

—Yes, if he put ticks in other boxes that would render his vote informal. Of course, if he places only the figure one on the Senate ballot paper , as I understand it-this is the answer to Senator Macklin's question-and then goes wrong after that I think his vote will be counted. So we will have the votes of people who mark only one box successfully still being counted.
—This is list voting you are talking about.

—Yes. That may be covered. To my mind, the acceptance of ticks and crosses will add further to the confusion of electors particularly when they are dealing with House of Representatives and Senate cards in joint elections. I think that quite often they will put their crosses down for, perhaps, all the Labor Party candidates and for no one else. I think the Government is only expanding the opportunity for confusion by permitting a tick or cross at all. I think the Opposition's argument is sound.

—The Government is trying in this measure to make voting easier for a whole range of people who have come to Australia from other countries, particularly European countries, who are used to voting under a list system. Anybody who has scrutineered in a close count knows the arguments that we have had about whether a figure is a continental one-some people put a tail before the figure one-or whether it is a tick. We are making sure that this situation does not occur in the future. We are trying to cut down on what I believe is a farcical situation in that one in 10 people throughout Australia votes informal for the Senate. The evidence given to the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform was that the vast majority of those people try to vote formal.

—I ask the Attorney-General ( Senator Gareth Evans) to respond to Senator Missen's point. Is Senator Missen correct in saying that, if a person in good faith puts a cross against five or six people in a party group, his vote, as the legislation is drafted, will then be invalid because it will not contain one cross, it will contain five or six crosses?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: — Just while the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) is thinking about that, I indicate that that is correct. This clause is designed just to apply to boxes at the top of a list voting ballot paper.
—If they don't take that option?

—Well, if they do not take that option and they do not complete the ballot paper in accordance with the rest of the Act in terms of filling out 90 per cent of squares and indicating their first preference their vote will be informal. Therefore, if someone puts down six crosses, the vote will be informal.

SPEECH.PARA: I also go on to say that if Senator Macklin's amendment were carried all that will happen will be that everyone in this chamber and in the parties will urge people to use numbers. If someone inadvertently puts a tick or a cross in the square-under the list system one registers one's vote in accordance with the instructions on a how to vote card-that person's vote will be valid provided there is only one tick or one cross in any one of the squares at the top of the ballot paper. The vote will be informal if there is more than one tick or cross in any one of the squares.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to Senator Peter Baume's question is buried in the mysterious drafting of page 125 of the Bill. Subsequently what it all amounts to, I am advised by the advisers in whom I have considerable confidence in these matters, is that, if there is a row of boxes across the top of the list voting ticket, as there will be, and someone fills in a (1) in one of them and then crosses in the others, applying the Missen theory of transferred hostility, under those circumstances the vote would be invalid. However, if the person writes in the numbers (1), (2), (3), (4), (5) the vote would be valid because there is a clear preference. That is a minor anomaly to that extent. Obviously the situation that is going to recur in practice infinitely more often is that someone is going to be wanting to record a preference for one of those boxes and, instead of putting a figure '1', will do as Senator Harradine says is the normal natural thing or as Senator Sibraa says is the normal reflex thing for particular people of European origin and put a cross or perhaps a tick. It is that situation that this provision is overwhelming directed towards even though the force of Senator Missen's point at the margin is acknowledged.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.
Clause agreed to.
Clauses 99 to 102-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 103.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Amendment No. (13) which has been circulated in the name of the Opposition covers the same matter that we have already disposed of. It seeks to take out the words 'a tick, a cross or'. I therefore do not intend to move this amendment which is really consequential to the one which has been disposed of. Amendment No. (14), which has been circulated by the Opposition, is one of two amendments which I understand the Committee will have before it in due course. This amendment seeks to clarify the means by which a vote can be deemed to be valid by the Senate and the extent to which the preferences which are expressed in that vote can be included in the count. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (14) Page 126, clause 103, proposed new paragraph 133B (1) (b), lines 8 to 13, leave out the paragraph, insert the following new paragraphs:
'' '(b) has-

(i) in a case where there are more than 9 candidates in the election-numbers, each being a number by which a preference is expressed, in not less than 90% of the squares opposite to the names of candidates; or

(ii) in any other case-numbers, each being a number by which a preference is expressed, in all the squares opposite to the names of candidates or in all those squares except one square that is left blank;''.

The proposed new section 133B is in two parts. The first part prescribes a series of conditions precedent to which an otherwise invalid ballot paper might be rendered valid. The second part provides that if the ballot paper complies with conditions precedent it may, at least to some extent, be taken to express a preference. We seek to amend the conditions precedent which are set out. We seek to make it a necessary requirement for the validity of ballot papers that the numbers stated thereon each be a number by which a preference is expressed. That is, we seek to have the numbers sequential up to the 90 per cent expressed in the amendment.

I turn to our amendment, which follows the form of the clause in the Bill. The clause in the Bill seeks to differentiate between the situation where there are nine or more than nine candidates and where there are less than nine candidates. We seek to keep it in that form. Our suggestion is this:
. . . where there are more than 9 candidates in the election-numbers-each being a number by which a preference is expressed, in not less than 90% of the squares opposite the names of candidates;

That means that if we went back to the election in which I was elected, where there were 73 candidates, we would then require something like 64 squares to be filled in, instead of the situation obtaining at present where one requires 72 out of the 73 squares to be filled in. That is the requirement under the present Act. The last square could be left blank under the present requirements. So the 90 per cent requirement allows a considerable latitude.

Where the Opposition differs from the Government is that we want those numbers to be sequential. We want the numbers to express a preference. We agree that with inadvertent mistakes, where someone might fill their paper in '1, 2, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10'-where they are clearly trying to express a preference and they leave out one number yet go all the way through-one can, in fact, by looking at that paper, determine a preference. The fact is that they have left out a number ; they have not repeated a number. As we have drawn up this amendment, it would permit that vote to be included because one could say that the preference had been expressed. To that extent, in a situation where a number has been left out we are not trying to have the vote excluded provided a preference has been expressed in the way the numbers have been written. The clause as it is written now simply says that numbers have to be written in a certain number of squares. Of course, one could write '1' for the candidate one wished to vote for. Then one could write '2' ten times and '3' ten times. One would be complying with the Government's requirement that 90 per cent of the squares have a number filled in .

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a very common phenomenon, of course, is it not?

—It does not matter whether it is common or not. We are trying to look at the electoral process. I am suggesting that what we are proposing by way of amendment actually, I think, seeks to do what is really behind the Government's intention in saying that numbers by which a preference is expressed must be written down. Suppose one wrote '1, 2, 2' and then completed his numbers. Because of the 90 per cent provision-the allowance for error-the vote would still be valid.
—So it should be.
—Wait a minute. We are not objecting if the voter wrote '1, 2, 2' and then '3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10'.
—That is rubbed out by your amendment.
—It is not rubbed out by our amendment because we have said that we have the 90 per cent-
—Read your own provisions, for God's sake. Read your own amendment. Where there is a doubling up, no preference is recorded.

—I am talking about the conditions precedent. I am not talking about the extent to which the preferences will be counted. In starting this discussion I drew the distinction that there were two matters. The first is the conditions precedent to the vote being a formal vote. The second is the extent to which the preferences will be recorded in the count. The Opposition draws a distinction between those two things. All I am discussing are the conditions precedent. I am suggesting that some amendment to what the Government has proposed is desirable. The amendment we have suggested is in the form that we have put forward.

SPEECH.PARA: I notice that the Australian Democrats have put forward another amendment which takes what one might care to call a more arbitrary approach. Although the Democrat amendment may be only a foreshadowed amendment at this moment, I wish to say that the only difficulty I have with that amendment is in the conditions which will apply for the smaller list where there are less than nine candidates. I think that the Democrats may have provided too many options for error. It may well be that we should ask the Democrats whether there is some way that they could look at the second part of their amendment, because the Democrats and the Liberal-National Party Opposition are both trying to achieve the same thing. We are trying to make it possible for the conditions precedent for a vote to be formal to be tightened up a bit and yet to accommodate what the Government is trying to seek; that is, that people should not inadvertently make their votes informal. We are trying to find a way to bring the votes into the count and yet to maintain what we think is a desirable electoral environment. I have moved amendment No. (14) circulated in the name of the Opposition. I may return to the argument, depending on the debate which will ensue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call the next speaker, I think I should draw the attention of the Committee to a procedural problem that we have. Both Senator Baume with the amendment that he has moved and Senator Macklin with a foreshadowed amendment are proposing to leave out the same paragraph and substitute different words. The problem is this: If Senator Baume's motion to leave out the words was not carried, Senator Macklin could not move his subsequent amendment. If both motions were carried but the words of both amendments were rejected, the paragraph would be left out completely. I suggest that the way out of this problem is that we deal first with Senator Baume's amendment and then give leave to Senator Macklin to move his amendment separately, even though that course is technically out of order. That, I think, is the only fair way to proceed. We will proceed then with Senator Baume's amendment No. (14).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure that Senator Baume is not trying deliberately to mislead the Senate as to the effect of his amendment, but that was the result of what he said. Accepting his distinction between conditions precedent and conditions subsequent and accepting that the subject matter of amendments (16) and (18) go to the conditions subsequent rather than to the conditions precedent, it is still the case that when the terms of his conditions precedent are examined closely, far from rendering formal a vote which meant 1, 2, 2, 3, 4, 5, right through to 90 per cent of the squares, that would in fact manifestly be informal, the reason being that, in the very language of Senator Baume's proposition, each number on the ballot paper up to the 90 per cent has to be a number by which a preference is expressed. The amendment states:

SPEECH.PARA: (i) in a case where there are more than 9 candidates in the election-numbers, each being a number by which a preference is expressed, in not less than 90% of the squares opposite to the names of candidates . . .
(ii) . . . each being a number by which a preference is expressed . . .

The reality is that when one doubles up on any numeral one is thereby not, in each of these two numerals which are thus doubled up, expressing a preference. One is certainly expressing a preference as between those two on which one has doubled up and all the other numbers. But as between those two alone, one is manifestly not expressing a preference. That is the difficulty with this proposal.

TALK.START.PARA: —If the comma were removed between 'expressed' and 'in', would that help? What we are trying to say is that 90 per cent of the preferences should be sequential.

—The thrust of the existing Government proposal is designed to cope with the second most common reason for informality; that is the doubling up on a particular number. The first most common reason, I suppose, is the jumping of a number; the omission of a number in the sequence.
—We do not know that. We suspect it is doubling up.

—I do not know. I bow to those around me. Whatever may be the case as to the numerical leader, these are the two common problems. Senator Baume has addressed himself to only one of them. In fairness, he ought to address himself to the other as well. As I understand it, Senator Macklin's foreshadowed amendment, while not going as far as the Government proposal, does allow three mistakes of some kind or other to be made, whether they are made by way of doubling up or whether they are mistakes by way of omission. The Government would much prefer to stick with what we have but will probably yield to the realities of the situation and accommodate Senator Macklin later. Senator Baume has to acknowledge that he just got it wrong when explaining the effect of what he is proposing. He may have some other argument up his sleeve, but we need to hear it.

—If the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) says that the amendment is wrong, does he not agree-my reading of the report likewise leaves the situation open-that if a person starts to write numbers but then loses interest and writes 5s, for example, in the rest of the squares, under the Government's proposal he has put numbers in not less than 90 per cent of the squares? They are not consequential numbers; they do not indicate a preference. There is confusion both in the report and in the provision. If the Attorney-General is not satisfied that the Opposition amendment picks up the problem entirely, what should be done? Surely what the Attorney-General is proposing to leave in the Bill has a great deal of obscurity. A vote might contain any old numbers. Someone might lose interest and write 5,000 or jumble numbers around with no sequence at all. I have seen ballots like that where people have lost interest. If 90 per cent of squares have numbers in them-any old numbers; not numbers which indicate a preference-is there not in the existing clause a problem which requires a more constructive attitude?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —It might be appropriate to give a little of the history of this area for Senator Baume and Senator Missen. If they are asking who is responsible for the Government's scheme, the author is sitting immediately to Senator Missen's left. It is well known that the Australian Labor Party has in its national platform a policy of optional preferential voting. We put it to the people at the last election. We do not hide from it even at this stage. We did not go ahead with that proposal, even though we had a majority on the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform and even though by far the vast majority of evidence given to the Committee was in favour of optional preferential voting, because it was indicated that three major parties, the Australian Democrats, the National Party and the Liberal Party, were afraid that we may get a system of first past the post voting through the back door. Therefore, we thrashed around for an alternative. That alternative, which was brought up by Senator Macklin, was that it will not matter so long as people make some attempt to put a number in every square. It will not matter whether they put 5,000 in three or four of the squares-at least that was our previous understanding of this proposal-but they have to be forced to make the effort; so that we do not get first past the post voting through the back door.

SPEECH.PARA: It is very difficult. We do not know whether the major informality occurs by jumping-that is, leaving out a number-or by duplication. My experience from three or four Senate scrutinies is that duplication is by far the biggest problem. We know that 77 per cent of informal voters have attempted at least to put the figure 1 in a square. If Senator Missen looks at the 1983 study he will see, in descending order, where the mistakes occur. About 10 per cent occur after No. 1. In the rest of the cases, it is about 2 per cent all the way down; 2 per cent made a mistake at No. 27 and 2 per cent made a mistake at No. 45.

TALK.START.PARA: —When they switch from one group to another?

—Probably from one group to another, although surprisingly it does not jump much. We have those problems. The Government intended in its proposal to introduce a vague form of optional preferential voting which would not lead to first past the post voting. We have tried to accommodate the groups on the other side, in spite of the fact that optional preferential voting is written in our platform and is in our policy and that we had a majority on the Committee. We did not use the majority on the Committee in an absolute vote, except on one occasion.

SPEECH.PARA: I doubt that what Senator Baume is suggesting would really help in reducing informality for those who, other than in list voting, exercise their normal rights. What Senator Macklin is suggesting would assist. I still oppose it, but the Government intends, I think, to accept it. I may say more about that when it comes up. Senator Evans is absolutely right when he points out that the Liberals ' suggestion would lead to informal voting where numbers are duplicated. The Liberal proposal is an improvement on the present situation. All I can say is that there is a lot of room for improvement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I feel a bit like what often happens when one is talking about a car crash. When the witnesses are asked what happened they talk about something quite different. The Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform, in its discussions on a Senate ballot paper, for the purposes of example tended to concentrate on the New South Wales ballot paper which traditionally tends to be of enormous length. I think there was agreement that if a person made a genuine attempt to go right the way through the ballot paper but inadvertently left some blanks or inadvertently doubled up somewhere along the line, it was unfair to penalise that person and declare that vote invalid. We then sought a method of overcoming the problem. A couple of proposals that I originally floated and which got refined in the Committee discussions, as I understand it, were that if it could be judged that a person had made a valid attempt-we thought by that that if a person had basically numbered the ballot paper consecutively, but had doubled up somewhere along the line or had skipped over a small team because that small team had been drawn between two larger teams; those types of fairly normal occurrences which happen to people when filling out forms-then we should try to accommodate that in the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's legislation, as it stands, conforms in some way with State Acts, particularly South Australian and New South Wales Acts. It seems to me that the legislation goes too far for the very reasons that Senator Missen raised. If a person placed a figure 1 and then put a whole series of 2s he could , in fact, subvert the legislation in that way. I have a later amendment which, if we leave that clause as it is, might still overcome the problem. The intent of the later amendment is not to allow a person to advertise in any way or for any person to do that type of thing. The only instructions that are able to be given are to tell a person to fill out the ballot paper in sequence right the way through.

I think the Liberal Party amendment goes too far in the other direction. That is how I read the first section. I must say that I agree with the Attorney- General (Senator Gareth Evans) that it would not allow one to do anything more than miss some numbers. I do not think that was the intent of the Committee. I think the Committee was suggesting that a person could leave some blanks and double up.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could you remove the comma from the amendment?

—I am not a lawyer, I am sorry. I am relying on the fact that the propositions that I put to the draftsman accommodate what I understood the Committee was suggesting. I foreshadowed that I will move amendments if the Liberal amendments are lost. I admit the point that Senator Baume raised that there is an arbitrariness about the number that one uses. Unfortunately, I think we are stuck with that. I could not think of any other way of trying to accommodate what the Committee was talking about.
—It was only for a small ballot paper.

—I have similar feelings about the small ballot paper. I was trying to go some way towards what the Government was attempting. I was trying to find a middle path between shoals in this case. My hope is that this amendment, coupled with a later amendment which I intend to move, will mean that there will not be any advertising, no promotions and nobody will be able to go around canvassing the proposition that this is what people ought to do. The only thing that people will be allowed to canvass will be the instructions contained on the ballot paper-that is, if one uses the second part of the ballot paper one must go from No. 1 right through to the end in consecutive numbers. That seems to be fair. I would have thought that with that conjunction of points no one would be in the position of being disadvantaged. I do not think that we will find any significant problems with the system. I say that, I suppose, as a matter of faith, because with the substantial changes that are now occurring it is a little difficult to know precisely what might happen. I could not see myself accepting the Liberal amendment, because it seems to cut out any chance of doubling up numbers and I thought that was what the Committee finally resolved, following discussion, ought to be allowed.

—Unfortunately, I think the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform has come down with a recommendation that I consider to be still too complicated. I would have liked to see a system such as the system for the New South Wales Legislative Council. Very briefly, if a person marks on a ballot paper 1, 2, 3 and 4, 4, 4, or whatever, the vote is counted up to the point where the mistake is made. The most common mistake that scrutineers find in Senate elections is not leaving out a number but a duplication of numbers. One of the most common mistakes that has been reported to me and that I have seen seems to occur between numbers 28 and 29. I have not been able to prove why but I have come up with a theory-that exhaustion is beginning to set in and the number 9 as it is printed on the Senate ballot paper is not the way that 99 per cent of the Australian people write it. When they are filling out their ballot papers they try to copy the printed 9, and it can look very much like an 8. This is where all the scrutineers say that many of the arguments start. I hope that the Commonwealth electoral officials will be able to look at the way the 9 is printed and perhaps print it in the way that most people in Australia write it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is quite clear that the amendment which we have moved will not attract sufficient support. Procedurally, it may be better if I seek leave to withdraw the amendment and thus allow the Australian Democrats' amendment to proceed. That may be the neatest way procedurally. Many of our amendments following this are consequential. One of the amendments we are proposing seeks to achieve precisely what Senator Sibraa thinks is necessary. It proposes that where people have doubled up on numbers preferences will be counted up to that point. I hope that that principle can be accepted and incorporated.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; amendment withdrawn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (25) Page 126, clause 103, lines 7 to 13, leave out proposed paragraph 133B (1) (b), insert the following paragraph:

''(b) has- (i) in a case where there are more than 9 candidates in the election -in not less than 90% of the squares opposite to the names of candidates, numbers in a sequence of consecutive numbers commencing with the number 1 or numbers that with changes to no more than 3 of them would be in such a sequence; or

(ii) in any other case-in all the squares opposite to the names of candidates or in all those squares except one square that is left blank, numbers in a sequence of consecutive numbers commencing with the number 1 or numbers that with changes to no more than 2 of them would be in such a sequence; and''.
(26) Page 126, clause 103, lines 19 to 27, leave out proposed paragraphs 133B ( 1) (f) and (g), insert the following paragraphs:

''(f) where numbers in squares opposite to the names of candidates are in a sequence of consecutive numbers commencing with the number 1-the voter shall be taken to have expressed a preference by the other number, or to have expressed preferences by the other numbers, in that sequence; and
''(g) the voter shall not be taken to have expressed any other preference.''.
(27) Page 126, clause 103, lines 39 to 43 and page 127, clause 103, lines 1 to 4, leave out proposed paragraphs 133B (2) (f) and (g), insert the following paragraphs and sub-section:

''(f) where numbers in squares opposite to the names of candidates are in a sequence of consecutive numbers commencing with the number 1-the voter shall be taken to have expressed a preference by the other number, or to have expressed preferences by the other numbers, in that sequence; and
''(g) the voter shall not be taken to have expressed any other preference.
''(3) In considering, for the purposes of sub-section (1) or (2), whether numbers are in a sequence of consecutive numbers, any number that is repeated shall be disregarded.''.

We are into an extremely technical area. The Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform had some very interesting submissions in relation to improving the method of counting Senate ballot papers. I think it might be admitted by everybody that it is a difficult area and therefore one is not surprised to find problems that may occur. Two possible results may arise out of clause 105 as it now stands-that is, too many people could be elected or too few people, depending on the circumstances. We hope that this clause will be subjected to pretty thorough analysis before we get anywhere near the next Senate election. I must admit that I am not at all confident that what we have here will not raise further problems the more we look at it.

I will give an example, particularly in relation to the important sub-section that I wish to leave out, and that is proposed sub-section 135 (24). Unfortunately it is a technical example, but I think when we get to the end of it we will see the result could be devastating if the sub-section were put into practice. If we consider an election to fill seven seats, which we will have at the next half Senate election-if we have one-with three million formal votes, the quota will be 375,001 votes. Suppose six vacancies are filled and that 50 of the ballot papers of one of the candidates-who has 375,101 first preferences, that is, a surplus of 100-on which he has first preference have been exhausted, and we have been through the fact that some votes can now be exhausted, the transfer value of each of his 375,101 papers will then be calculated. If we add the exhausted votes we work out that the figure will be 0.013 of a vote, and that of course under the Commonwealth Electoral Act must be discarded. The six quotas each have 375,001 and six candidates have been elected which means we have got rid of 2,250,006 of the original votes leaving the magic number of 749, 994 votes. When this is actually worked out it means that on the decreasing quota, which is contained in sub-section 135 (24), we would have got to the position that the votes remaining for the continuing candidates-that is the number I have just mentioned-would amount to more than two quotas, although there is only one remaining vacancy.

If people contemplate us getting to that situation we would then presumably have to have a new election because we would then have the very real possibility of two people getting quotas out of the remaining votes left for one position. It is completely unacceptable that even that theoretical position should be contained within the Act. I am working on only 50 exhausted votes, which I believe would be a very small number of votes for the last position. If one started taking them up-do not forget that we are allowing three mistakes-the number of exhausted votes could be much higher and the higher the number gets the more likely is the occurrence, under the decreasing quota, of getting to this very point.

I must admit that the Australian Democrats do not agree with the operation proposed here but the reality is that it will stay in the legislation so I believe that it should be done correctly. Effectively, the purpose of my amendment is to eliminate what might end up being an awful embarrassment. Again, the possibility of it occurring is remote. I accept that, but we do not want the povision left as it it. Basically, it presents something very similar to what is known as the Alabama paradox. Following many discussions in the United States, designed to work out the number of House of Representatives seats, it became possible by alighting on certain numbers, to effect a total increase in House numbers but actually a decrease in the allocations of certain States. That may seem odd but it is a matter of the way in which the quotas operate. —Alabama certainly thought of it first; the problem arose first there, but the process has been used all the way through. I gave the Colorado example because it was much more specific. With Alabama it never came about because the Alabama people were sufficiently strong to avoid that.

AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL RAILWAYS COMMISSION BILL 1983

The purpose of this Bill and the associated Australian National Railways Commission (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill is to repeal the Australian National Railways Act 1917 and replace it with legislation appropriate to the Commission's role as a commercially oriented business undertaking operating in the 1980s. The Bill defines precisely the Commission's powers and responsibilities and enhances its opportunity to operate commercially in competitive markets.

Let me make one point perfectly clear at the outset. We believe the Federal Government has a major role to play in improving the efficiency of railways in Australia's national transport system. This role has not always been recognised- the most obvious example being that as a result of parochial thinking in past years, Australia now has five separate rail systems using three different gauges . Previous Federal governments of various political persuasions have made major efforts to overcome the difficulties of this legacy by attempting to unify and standardise the national rail network.

Rail's performance can, and must, be improved. This can be done by the introduction of more flexible and more commercial management and a more consistent national transport policy than in the past. The long term viability of rail systems depends not only upon adequate infrastructure but also upon effective pricing, marketing, organisation and personnel policies. With this legislation, we are providing AN with the powers to operate in this manner. Railway operations should not concentrate solely on traditional areas of business. We expect railways as dynamic organisations to be looking for new traffic to expand its business. By promoting business growth, railways can increase efficiency and productivity and help generate additional employment opportunities. An improved industrial relations environment, better management and rational investment plans will reduce transit times, improve reliability and increase the opportunity for real growth in rail business.

Unfortunately, funding is simply not available to undertake all of the investment needs of railways immediately. All governments currently face extremely difficult budgetary situations. Because of this, further investment in rail programs will need to be guided by a careful and responsible assessment of priorities. A good case in point is the Darwin-Alice Springs railway. No one would deny that if resources were no object it may be desirable to construct the railway. This Government is committed to upgrading transport services to the Northern Territory and the inquiry being conducted by Mr David Hill will determine the facts on whether the rail or road option is the more economically and socially sound.

Notwithstanding the current difficult economic conditions, governments are, as much as possible, pressing ahead with major railway projects. They are showing their confidence in railways' future by committing further funds for new projects which will expand the overall tasks performed by railways. With adequate investment and improved efficiency Australian Railways will play an essential role in the development of Australia for the rest of this century and beyond. It is a matter of special concern that the national rail network operates efficiently and meets national needs. In addition to infrastructure, railways must also be properly equipped with manpower and management resources and practices necessary to perform that role. A healthy working relationship between labour and management is as important for railways as it is in any industry.

Co-operation and consultation are the basic working principles of this Government. Since his appointment, the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) has initiated regular meetings with the unions and AN to discuss issues of mutual concern. This process of consultation and co-operation is being expanded both at Ministerial level and within AN. In this way, AN's employees have a greater opportunity to contribute to improvements in AN and to have an input into policy.

The ANRC Bill has as one of its objectives the establishment of a unified organisation dedicated to operating a sound and efficient railway system. It is up to AN and its employees to grasp the chance for success and work hard to achieve it. The Government can set the climate but management and unions together must accept the challenge. In AN, the Australian Government's own railway system, these things are happening. For instance, the Commission is upgrading its marketing effort to ensure that it wins its share of the freight available, and is seeking to improve the information available to management.

Honourable senators will recall that it was the previous Labor Government which began the Tarcoola-Alice Springs railway, completed in 1980. The new standard gauge line between Adelaide and Crystal Brook has also commenced operating successfully, notwithstanding the overall adverse economic conditions. In the first ten months of operation, over 1.1 million tonnes of freight have been carried on the line. Work is proceeding on the Adelaide rail passenger terminal, a new interstate terminal being built as Keswick. It will commence passenger operations early next year.

Along with many other transport enterprises, AN's financial performance has suffered as a result of the economic downturn and severe drought. Honourable senators will recall that on assuming office, we were told that an additional $ 34.5m was needed in 1982-83 to meet Commission losses-a 50 per cent increase over the original allocation, giving a total contribution of $106 million. I will describe later the steps we are implementing to avoid a repeat of this experience. In 1983-84, the Government is providing a revenue supplement of $85m or some $21m less than in 1982-83.

The Minister for Transport has also asked the Commission to identify those services where it believes Government support should be provided to maintain these operations. Over the years it is clear that railways have undertaken tasks that they would not do if they operated solely on commercial criteria. In order that the Commission can operate efficiently in terms of both its commercial and non-commercial activities it is clear that this latter group has to be identified so that the cost can clearly be seen and taken into account. It is then for others, rather than AN, to determine whether these services should be maintained and if so, to be prepared to meet the costs associated with the provision of the services. Obviously it is incumbent upon Government to fulfil this role. In this manner AN's performance can be judged against broad commercial criteria and community services can be undertaken without detriment to the Commission's overall financial performance. This approach accords with the recommendations made by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure in its 1982 report on the Australian National Railways Commission. It also accords with the Government's social audit policy in transport.

As well as completion of the Adelaide-Crystal Brook project, capital works to be undertaken this year include continuation of the rehabilitation of the Tasmanian rail system, the purchase of ten new locomotives and construction of AN's new headquarters building. In total, these projects will cost $40.0m in 1983-84. Further support for AN is being provided under the Commonwealth's own share of the community employment program, CEP. All of the $1.6m allocated to AN under CEP in 1983-84 will be used to employ 130 extra people for railway and re- sleepering projects in South Australia and Western Australia. What I have described are a number of the major initiatives this Government has already taken to prepare AN for the challenge of the 1980s.

The Bill now before us will provide the framework under which AN can function- as a commercially oriented transport authority. The legislation contains many provisions of an earlier Bill introduced into the House of Representatives with bipartisan support by the former Minister for Transport and Construction. I commend him for this action. Explanatory memoranda have been circulated to assist honourable senators in their consideration of the Bill.

The Commission, as established under the Australian National Railways Act 1917, will continue in existence. An important feature of this Bill is that the powers of the Commission have been comprehensively defined. Ministerial intervention in day to day activities is minimised while retaining ministerial oversight in critical areas. This ensures that the Commission is provided with that necessary flexibility to operate commercially but remains properly accountable to the Parliament. Of the changes to our predecessors' Bill, the most important provisions of the legislation relate to the accountability of the Commission for attaining financial targets. We are satisfied these changes are necessary if AN is to be clearly responsible for its financial performance against defined criteria. Certain other clauses have been streamlined in order to simplify the legislation. AN's past financial performance, similar to other railway systems, leaves considerable scope for improvement. We believe that improvement will in part be achieved through greater financial accountability. As I said earlier, the Minister for Transport has asked AN to identify its community service obligations. Taking factors like these into account, AN will be provided with a revenue supplement in the Budget context. It will then be AN's responsibility to ensure that this financial target is at least achieved if not bettered. To do this the Commission will be able to be more flexible and to readily adapt to changing conditions.

This Bill will ensure that the annual revenue supplement decided in the Budget becomes the level of contribution that the Government provides to the Commission for that year. But we will not be unreasonable about this. AN will be required to submit to the Minister for Transport a financial target for each year not later than 60 days before the start of that financial year. The Government will then consult with the Commission to reach a fair and just figure involving responsible use of the taxpayer's money.AN will then be responsible for reviewing at least six monthly progress towards achieving the financial target. If it is not on target AN must then determine what actions it will take to meet the financial objective by the end of the year.

Notwithstanding all that this review process involves, should AN's operating results then indicate the target will not be met, the Commission will be required to inform the Minister for Transport of the measures it will take to meet this shortfall. The legislation provides that these measures cannot include further recourse to the Budget.

Before implementing its proposed measures, the Commission will seek any Government approvals that might be required in the normal way. All borrowings, for example, are subject to the Treasurer's approval.

The success of this approach depends largely on the ability of the Commission and the Government to consult to determine a realistic annual revenue supplement . The Government will be working with AN's Commission and staff to ensure that this is achieved.

On the basis that a realistic revenue supplement is determined, AN will then have the opportunity to enjoy the benefits of any improvements above that level it might achieve during the year. Clearly then the financial target will be the benchmark against which AN's performance can be judged.

The division between AN's powers and responsibilities and those of the Minister for Transport are clearly distinguished in the Bill. This arrangement emphasises the need for AN to operate as a commercially oriented transport authority. The responsibility for commercial initiatives rests squarely with the Commission.

AN's greater commercial freedom will be evident in relation to day to day matters such as the fixing of fares and freight rates. AN is obliged by the Bill to determine the principles which it proposes to apply in order to fix rates of charges for prescribed services.

This concept was included in amendments which the Minister for Transport recently introduced to the Australian Shipping Commission Act, the ASC Act. It will provide approved parameters within which AN will be able to determine and vary fares and freight rates thus avoiding excessive Government intervention in routine operating decisions.
These principles are to be determined by AN and advised to the Minister who may accept or redetermine the principles that are to form the basis of AN's charges.
As indicated earlier, the Bill enables the Minister for Transport to direct the Commission to undertake non-commercial activities which may be socially desirable.

If the Government requires AN to engage in particular activities for social or other reasons, then the Minister for Transport will issue a direction to the Commission. AN would then be reimbursed for any losses involved in carrying out the Minister's directions. Such directions are required to be tabled in Parliament.

Although the Bill removes a number of constraints, reasonable provisions for ministerial oversight will remain. For contracts valued at more than $2m approval of the Minister for Transport will be required. The Minister for Transport intends to use the provision to vary this level by regulation to maintain the current level in real terms. Such action would, I expect, be undertaken annually. Ministerial approval must be obtained before AN takes part in the formation of companies or enters into agreements for lease financing.

AN will have power to construct small extensions to its existing railway network. Previously it was necessary for all railway construction to be approved by an Act of Parliament. Under the proposed provision legislation will only be required when railways over 25 kilometres along are built. This power would allow AN to further its business interests by construction of sidings or spur lines to clients' premises. This will increase the ability of AN to compete with other transport operators.

The Commission's powers relating to the operation, maintenance and construction of railways, including the right to enter and occupy land have been modernised. This is consistent with the powers provided to other statutory authorities and will help ensure that AN is able to fulfil its proper functions in a timely and efficient manner.

There are some changes to the Commission itself. There will be an option for appointing the Chairman on either a part time or full time basis. The Bill also provides for a Deputy Chairman to be appointed. The statutory retiring age of 65 for part time commissioners will be removed.

The rights of employees of the Commission including those transferred from the former Tasmanian Railways and South Australian Railways have not been changed. But there have been improvements in the area of personnel practices. Conditions of employment of an AN staff will no longer be determined by the Public Service Board. Ministerial approval of salaries of senior positions will not be required . Such matters are more properly a matter for the commercial judgement of AN.

There are several other provisions which I would like to also briefly mention. The accident reporting provisions have been revised to specify the types of accidents that must be reported to the Minister. The Minister's power to initiate independent investigation of accidents has also been strengthened.

The current legislation has a number of separate provisions covering different kinds of offences. These have been replaced by the one provision, which identifies the single serious offence of endangering the safety of the railways and provides for a substantial penalty.

The Commission also has the power to make by-laws to protect railway users and property; penalties of up to $500 can be prescribed for offences. Any such by- laws will be subject to parliamentary scrutiny in the same manner as regulations .
This Bill is not a money Bill and therefore has no direct financial impact on the Budget.
The legislation is an important step in giving AN the responsibilities and powers to increase the productivity efficiency and competitiveness of its railway operations.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL RAILWAYS COMMISSION (TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS AND CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1983

This Bill is complementary to the Australian National Railways Commission Bill 1983. Its purpose is threefold. It repeals the Australian National Railways Act 1917 with effect from the date of proclamation of the new ANRC Act. It makes necessary arrangements to ensure continuity in the Commission's operations. In particular, it continues the appointment and terms and conditions of service of the Chairman, commissioners, General Manager, officers and employees of the Commission as if the Act had not been repealed. Lastly, it changes references in other legislation where this is necessary. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Attorney-General to an interview with Mrs Joan Coxsedge on this morning's AM program in which she said that Mr Justice Hope was a totally unsatisfactory person to investigate the Australian Secret Intelligence Service incident in Melbourne because 'he has shown himself in the past to be partisan as far as secret agencies are concerned'. She further said:

QUESTION.PARA: He certainly showed it in his questioning of the Combe/Ivanov Affair.

Will the Attorney-General repudiate entirely these disgraceful allegations about a judge whom the Government has now chosen on two occasions to make specific inquiries on its behalf in relation to activities of intelligence agencies, as well as having chosen him to make the general inquiry into intelligence agencies ? Will the Attorney-General further consider whether Mrs Coxsedge in what she said is in contempt of the Royal Commission on Australia's Security and Intelligence Agencies and, if so, will he take appropriate action?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mrs Coxsedge's views on the subject of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation and all related matters are well known. I have been bearing the brunt of them for some considerable number of years, both inside and outside the Party. I think the Australian Labor Party and this Government have a strong commitment to the tradition of robust free speech on matters of public concern and lively public interest. We have a very great reluctance to see the law of contempt being used to stifle vigorous criticism of public figures, be they judicial or otherwise.

ANSWER.PARA: I do believe the criticism of Mr Justice Hope is wholly unjustified, but there is no way in which I personally would wish to initiate any proceedings by way of contempt so far as the particular statements reportedly made by Mrs Coxsedge are concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Attorney-General seen reports that the South Australian Government has been forced, by the Liberal Opposition and the Australian Democrats in that State, to review proposals for the uniform classification of videotapes? What implications does this action have for the implementation of a national uniform classification scheme for videotapes?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bolkus will not be surprised to hear me say that it does not help the cause of the uniform implementation of a videotape system for that aspiration to appear to have broken down in South Australia. I understand that some further consideration is being given by all the parties in South Australia to this issue and that it may be that the initial reactions that occurred in the South Australian Parliament this week will, after further reflection, not necessarily prevail.

ANSWER.PARA: I think there has been an enormous amount of misunderstanding in South Australia as to what is proposed in the uniform classification system and in particular the supposedly voluntary character of that classification system. It is the case that under the uniform proposals that all Attorneys-General and appropriate censorship Ministers agreed to a few months ago, there is to be no compulsion so far as the classification process in concerned.

However, the sanction for not seeking the classification of tapes is that under the proposed scheme of uniform legislation the vendor or hirer of such unclassified material exposes himself or herself to the full range of sanctions in the ordinary law of obscenity, or laws governing the sale, hire or display of obscene articles. If someone goes through the process of seeking a classification and then sells or hires the product in accordance with the classification, be it 'R', 'X' or whatever is given to it, that person is completely immune from prosecution. As such, there is an enormous practical incentive for persons to participate in that classification system.

There is a very real sense in which it can be said that the system is not voluntary at all. When that is better understood in South Australia and the other jurisdictions which will be progressively considering this, it will be appreciated that we have here a law which does effectively strike a balance not only between the demands for free speech and free access to this material on the one hand but also the very legitimate community interest in not having put on public display matter which is manifestly offensive and regarded as obscene by significant sections of the community.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Attorney-General. Will the Government's request to Mr Justice Hope to inquire into the Australian Secret Intelligence Service incident at the Sheraton Hotel include the possibility of a deliberate attempt to discredit Australian's security service? Will the Government table the exact terms of its request to the Royal Commissioner?

—I must admit the thought did cross my mind that there may have been some infiltration of ASIS by the socialist Left as being the only possible explanation that had any rationality about it of the events of Wednesday night. I have no idea whether any attempt has been made to discredit the security organisations that may have been reflected in the course of events which Mr Justice Hope will inquire into. But I assure the honourable senator that the terms of reference of Mr Justice Hope's inquiry in this respect are undoubtedly wide enough as they presently stand to enable him to satisfy himself and, in turn I believe the Parliament, as to whether there is any justification for that kind of suspicion.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Will the Attorney- General table in the Senate the exact terms of the request to the Royal Commissioner?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since I have been so pre-occupied this morning with the Commonwealth Electoral Legislation Amendment Bill, I have not caught up with the formal developments in this respect.

ANSWER.PARA: As I understand it, the view has been taken by the Government that parts A and B of the existing terms of reference of the Royal Commission on Australia's Security and Intelligence Agencies are perfectly wide enough to accommodate the inquiry in question, because Mr Justice Hope would, in the ordinary course, have been dealing with ASIS and this is obviously something within that larger frame of reference. TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Attorney-General seen a joint media release by the Musicians' Union of Australia, Actors Equity of Australia, the Australian Record Industry Association and the Australian Book Publishers Association, welcoming his statement on a possible royalty on blank tapes? Does the Government plan to introduce such a royalty, which could help maintain employment for Australian performers and workers in the Australian record industry?

—I have seen the release to which the honourable senator referred. When the review is completed I will assess all the responses and take into account the further matters relating to employment in the industry that Senator Zakharov has mentioned. I expect to be in a position early in 1984 to take firm proposals to Cabinet and Caucus in this respect and to prepare a Bill which will lie on the table for public comment.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

I noted Mr Hayden's statement that the Australian Secret Intelligence Service exercise 'took place without my knowledge'. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Attorney-General to the theory of ministerial responsibility which he adopted in a debate in the Senate on 7 September last year when the quoted and embraced a statement by Mr Malcolm Fraser, who said:

QUESTION.PARA: It is certainly true that Ministers cannot be aware of everything that occurs in their departments. They ought to be aware of all the major matters and therefore can be clearly and directly responsible for them but if a major blunder occurred in a Department, of real importance to Australia, and if the Minister were unaware of it, that Minister should accept responsibility for the mistakes of his Department and offer to resign.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Social Security. There have been a number of claims that many supporting parent beneficiaries are attempting to play the pay-day system by claiming separation before a pension payday and then reconciling shortly afterwards. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to these claims? Can he say whether there is any substance to them and, if so what steps he has taken, or will take, to address this problem?

—At various times I have received, as I think all Ministers for Social Security have, claims about groups in the community who, allegedly, play the social security system in the manner and similar manners to that which Senator Crowley has described. It is frequently the supporting parents who are accused of doing this sort of thing. It seems unfortunate in our community that there is a general acceptance that aged pensioners, invalid pensioners and widowed pensioners deserve their pensions while supporting parents are the butt of jibes and the source of suspicion. In recent times there have been claims that supporting parent beneficiaries have been manipulating the system by going on and off supporting parent benefit by claiming separation, then reconciliation and separation again. In the light of this, it was decided particularly in Western Australia that an investigation would be made to see just how frequently supporting parents did this sort of thing. No evidence was found that this occurred at any frequent levels at all. The Department of Social Security does keep an eye on this sort of think to make sure that the system is not manipulated in this way or in other ways. There will always be a small group of people, whatever benefit they receive, who will try to cheat the system and not play it fairly but I have no evidence that this is happening in this area. However, we will continue to monitor the situation and make sure that such a practice does not develop.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. How many community employment projects have been approved so far in South Australia? How many jobs have been generated by these projects?
