—I draw the attention of the Attorney-General to statutory rule No . 274 of 1983.
—Is that what you have in your hand?

—Yes. It is entitled 'Electoral and Referendum Regulations Amendment'. This statutory rule was made as long ago as 11 November. It has now been printed and is available to the public but it has not yet been tabled in this Parliament. I ask the Attorney-General: Do these regulations provide a new and special form of ballot paper for the 1984 referendums to include a brief description of the proposed laws to change the directions to the voters and the format of the questions to be submitted, but which now does not contain the long title of each proposed law as has been the case in all constitutional questions since 1967? Why has the Government not yet tabled the regulations so that the Parliament can have an opportunity of examining them? Is the Government frightened that the Parliament might criticise the new form of questions and perhaps even move to disallow them? Why has the Government not given the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances an opportunity to consider these regulations prior to the referendum? Is it a fact that the Government intends to delay tabling the regulations until the last day of sitting so that there will be no time for that Committee to examine the regulations and no time for this Parliament to consider the regulations? Is this not just another shonky action? Is it not a fact that this Government continues to preach consensus but dogmatically practises the rule of 'big brother knows best', stifles debate and treats the people of Australia as fools?

—It is completely news to me that the regulations have not been tabled in Parliament. Certainly they should have been at this stage. I readily acknowledge the force of what Senator Lewis says in this respect. If he wants to get down to the business of getting them before the Committee straightaway and to debate the matter in some way before we get up-it seems as though we still have plenty of time-I will be amply willing to accommodate him. There has been absolutely no intention on my part to stifle any debate in this respect. Indeed, I have discussed the subject matter of these regulations with Senator Durack on behalf of the Opposition.
—After you had made them, I think.

—That is true but I told the honourable senator about them so at least the honourable senator would be aware of them. I also discussed them with the honourable senator beforehand. He indicated that he was not too keen about changing them but, then again, he has never been too keen about changing anything.
—Why haven't they been tabled?

—I do not know why they have not been tabled, Senator Chaney. I will do my best to find out. There certainly has been no intention whatsoever to deny in any way parliamentary scrutiny of this. The proposed modifications to the format of the ballot paper are as follows: The short title of the Bill is contained which, up until 1967, was the only reference point in referendums. After 1967 the long title was spelt out and the short title was abandoned, for reasons which remain obscure. The short title is followed by a short and non-tendentious description of the subject matter in language which--

—It is so non-tendentious that, in relation to simultaneous terms, there is a reference to the variation of senators' terms accordingly, which is lacking from the long title of the Bill, and which was the source of considerable criticism from Senator Durack. We can debate the detail of this at some later time. But the object of the exercise was simply to put before the electorate, in language that was intelligible and non-tendentious, the particular matters in respect of which they are being asked to pass. The situation has been that with the recent run of referendums ballot papers, designed as they have been around the long title of the respective Bills, have been almost totally unintelligible and incomprehensible to anyone except persons familiar with statutory language and the approach to these things. They have been full of jargon, such as 'prescribed laws'. The whole thing has been very complex. No doubt that has been of great advantage to those who see the referendum process as an opportunity to bemuse and befuddle the voters. Those who want no cases to be put see a considerable advantage in a ballot paper being unintelligible. The rest of us do not take that view and I do not think it will be a view shared across party lines, particularly in the context of the referendum proposals which have had the cross-party support that these have had. So the Government has nothing to apologise for in this respect, except possibly for some procedural defect which I will ensure is remedied immediately.
—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I will not make all the smart comments which come to mind; I simply ask: Which Minister will have the responsibility of tabling this regulation?
—Since they are amendments to the electoral legislation-
—It is signed by Mr Beazley.

—Yes, I believe it is the responsibility of the Special Minister of State, because regulations were signed by and initiated by Mr Beazley. It appears there has been some snafu in the system somewhere. We will untangle it and ensure that ample opportunity is given for debate on these matters.

—Did the Attorney-General, at the invitation of the Prime Minister, meet with the Prime Minister and Archbishop Carroll of Canberra-Goulburn to discuss several misgivings held by the Archbishop concerning the Sex Discrimination Bill, particularly in regard to the alleged application of the Bill to the provision of medical services relating to abortion and in regard to the actual application of the Bill in relation to non-government schools? Was the Government able to respond to the representations made by the Archbishop? Is any such response embodied in the new Bill brought into this place on Tuesday last.

—The Prime Minister and I met with Archbishop Carroll on 10 November and at that meeting a number of matters were discussed and concerns clarified. Following the meeting the Prime Minister wrote, on 21 November, to Archbishop Carroll agreeing to consider further points made at the meeting with a view to accommodating the Archbishop's concerns. Archbishop Carroll has since replied to the Prime Minister's letter and has indicated that the correspondence which has been exchanged will in due course be published in the Catholic Press. When the Archbishop takes that step, honourable senators will be able to see for themselves the full range of matters that were dealt with and the diversity of reactions that occurred. But I can say this: In the redrafted Sex Discrimination Bill which was introduced by Senator Ryan on 29 November, a number of concerns raised by Archbishop Carroll and others have been accommodated. Changes have been included in the draft Bill which reflect this. I refer in particular to clause 32 on services, clause 37 on religious bodies and clause 38 on educational institutions.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Since the Archbishop has apparently indicated a willingness to put the correspondence in the public arena by publishing it in the Catholic Press, can the Attorney table that correspondence, either today or perhaps next Tuesday if the Archbishop wants to take the first running on publishing the material?
—I think I would prefer to consult through the Prime Minister's office with the Archbishop's office as a matter of courtesy before putting the material on the public record.

—My question is directed to the Attorney-General. I refer to the answer he gave to a question asked by Senator Durack earlier today, to the Attorney's apparent commitment to Mrs Joan Coxsedge's right of free speech and the Attorney's statement that he would not be prepared to do anything about possible contempt of the Royal Commission-
—I said 'to initiate'.

—Or to initiate any action with respect to possible contempt of the Royal Commission on Australian Security and Intelligence Agencies. I remind the Attorney-General of the contrasting stance of the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, who early in August this year responded to a statement made by Mr Peacock which made some comment on the effect of the Prime Minister's evidence before the Royal Commission. At that time Mr Hawke was reported as being furious. He made a statement that what Mr Peacock said was wrong and defamatory. He indicated that the matter would be referred to the Royal Commission through the Government's counsel, Mr McHugh, that the Government's counsel would be instructed to raise the matter before the Royal Commission and that what Mr Peacock said was a contempt of the Commission and, to quote Mr Hawke, 'needs to be dealt with'. I remind the Attorney-General that as a result of that several newspapers censored articles which they had written, which included reference to what Mr Peacock had said, and that in fact counsel for the Commonwealth, under instruction, presumably from the Attorney-General, raised the matter with the Royal Commission and said that Mr Hawke had been traduced and defamed.
—Order! I invite the Leader of the Opposition to ask his question.

—Thank you, Mr President. That was all I wished to remind the Attorney of and I now ask him: Does he agree that there appears to be one rule for Labor politicians and another rule for Liberal politicians?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was the case that Mr Hawke was traduced and defamed by the performance of the Leader of the Opposition in relation to the Hope Royal Commission. It is a matter for judgment as to whether the Hope Commission was brought into disrepute by what Mr Peacock said to the extent that would have justified a cause of action in contempt against Mr Peacock. They are two separate issues. On the issue of contempt, I have made my position abundantly clear in public on a number of occasions; that I believe that the law of contempt has been over-used in relation to the activities of royal commissions and tribunals-royal commissions and committees of inquiry in particular- investigating matters of public importance as distinct, that is, from the courts which are actually administering justice in the context of civil and criminal proceedings.

ANSWER.PARA: With that in mind, I have referred the whole question of contempt to the Australian Law Reform Commission in order that we might be able to bring some better balance into that law than is the case at the moment. There will no doubt be differences of opinion as between Government Ministers from time to time-not that I am suggesting there is any difference of opinion between myself and the Prime Minister-on this issue or the policy issues underlying it at the moment. But that does not alter the fundamental point that the bias of the law, in my opinion, should be very much in favour of continuing to allow robust free speech when it comes to the contributions to debate on matters of lively current interest.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. I welcome the Attorney-General's defence of robust free speech, but my question related to consistency of action by the Government. If he claims, as he appeared to in that answer, that Mr Hawke was traduced and defamed by Mr Peacock, does he agree that the Royal Commissioner has been traduced and defamed by Mrs Coxsedge's remarks which go to his partiality and that, therefore, in the interests of consistency, since the Government saw fit to refer it to the Royal Commission with respect to Mr Peacock, it would appear that if the Government is to be consistent it will do the same thing with respect to Mrs Coxsedge?

—All sorts of questions are in issue in the earlier matter involving Mr Justice Hope as to the implications of what was being said by Mr Peacock for the future evidence of witnesses to come before the Commission. The issues do not appear to be the same in any sense in relation to Mrs Coxsedge. If the Commissioner should take the view that the language employed by Mrs Coxsedge is such as to put his Commission at risk in terms of its capacity to carry on this inquiry effectively, no doubt I will hear from the Commissioner in due course. As the law now stands, the Commissioner cannot actually set in train the contempt proceedings in that situation; he can only refer them to the Attorney- General. I am not prepared to initiate any proceedings, as I have indicated, in this respect but should the Commissioner feel that such proceedings should be contemplated, I will take the appropriate course of action and consider the matter then.

—Is the Minister assisting the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment aware that the Townsville Daily Bulletin today reports the unanimous decision of the Charters Towers Council to call on the Federal Government to extend the period during which the community can fully consider the environmental impact statement on the proposed uranium mine at Ben Lomond in North Queensland? In view of the extreme importance of this matter, can the Minister report on the possibility of the Department of Home Affairs and Environment being able to respond positively to this request?

—The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided me with some information on the Ben Lomond uranium proposal referred to by Senator Reynolds. The Commonwealth Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act requires that draft environmental impact statements be released for public review for a period of not less than 28 days. However, in relation to major mining proposals it is customary to make environmental impact statements available for public review and comment for longer periods. In the past such statements on uranium mining projects have been made available for comment for up to 67 days. The Government is sympathetic to the request for an extension to the public review period for the Ben Lomond EIS and negotiations with the company to secure an extension beyond the current closing date of 23 December 1983 are now being pursued.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs. Is it true that the Government has rejected repeated requests to give a commitment to fund the university component of the new Queen Victoria Medical Centre in Melbourne and that this is causing expensive delays to the project? Is it true that the Government of Victoria has agreed to proceed with the building of the university component providing the Federal Government will specify a future date on which it will fund the project? Is it true that if such a commitment is not given this year the entire project may be delayed at a cost of up to $90,000 a day, despite the fact that the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission has been aware of the need for such funding for at least 10 years, and that unless the university component of the project proceeds it may be necessary for Monash University to close its medical school because of the lack of clinical teaching facilities? What is the Government doing about this very unsatisfactory situation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —None of the assertions made in Senator Hamer's question is true. The question reveals an ignorance of the way in which decisions about the funding of projects in the tertiary education sector are made. Monash University has submitted a concept proposal to the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission for the construction of clinical teaching facilities at the Queen Victoria Medical Centre. It has been advised that the proposal has been approved in concept at a figure of $6m in June 1982 cost values. Such approval indicates the Commission's agreement that the proposal warrants consideration along with other projects as funds become available.

ANSWER.PARA: The timing of the total project is a matter for the Victorian Government. The Victorian Government has sought a commitment as to the timing of any Commonwealth contribution to the cost of constructing the facilities. The proposal will have to compete annually with other capital developments in higher education for the share of available resources. The university must now keep the proposal before the Commission until it is judged to have reached a high enough priority to be recommended for inclusion in the capital program for a particular year.

The arrangements for the construction of the Queen Victoria Medical Centre are the responsibility of the State Government. The relocation of the Centre has been under consideration in Victoria for many years. However, no formal request for funds for the construction of new clinical teaching facilities was submitted to the CTEC until early this year. I know of no proposal to close Monash University's medical school. Such a proposal would be of great concern to the Commonwealth and to the people of Victoria.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Veterans' Affairs whether he can supply details in relation to the operation of the recently established Vietnam Veterans Counselling Service in Townsville and Canberra. Particularly, can he indicate the client usage in Townsville and in Canberra? Can he also inform the Senate whether the client usage of those two centres indicates that there should be an extension to the services provided by them to the veterans? If so, can he further inform the Senate whether any action is proposed by the Government in relation to those centres?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Within the last six weeks the Government has opened two new counselling centres for those who served in Vietnam, one at Townsville and the other in Canberra. This service has exceeded our expectations to the extent that veterans have immediately responded to it. For example, in Townsville, in the first few weeks more than 50 veterans sought personal assistance-in some cases their wives and families did so also-and in Canberra, where the service commenced only a couple of weeks ago, in the first week some 17 availed themselves of the service. That means that the Government's decision to open these centres has been widely supported and appreciated by those who need that sort of assistance, that is, those who served in Vietnam.

ANSWER.PARA: Generally speaking, whilst there has been a relative decline for the month of September there was a marked increase overall in the usage of the centres last month. This, of course, I think confirms the wise decisions of governments, past and present, to establish the centres throughout Australia. Of course, if it is found that other centres need to be opened in provincial areas the Government will look very sympathetically at such requirements.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, relates to Press reports emanating from the Indonesian Press on the continuing killing of suspected criminals by para- military death squads. Will the Minister comment on these most recent reports and, in particular, the claim by one well placed source that some 1,400 known or suspected criminals have been executed by para-military squads which have the support of several government and military officials? Because of the renewed reports appearing in the Indonesian Press, I ask the Minister: Firstly, what details does the Government have of these most recent extra-judicial killings; secondly, will the Government express to the Indonesian Government the concern of the Australian people about these brutal executions and ask that urgent action be taken to prohibit the continuance of such abhorrent and inhumane practices?

—It is difficult for anyone not to feel concerned about the reports which have been emerging from Indonesia and to which Senator Missen referred. But, as to the detailed substance of his question and the nature of the Government's reaction, I think it preferable to refer the matter to the Minister for Foreign Affairs for detailed reply which I will undertake to produce as soon as possible.

—Is the Minister for Social Security aware that although he provided a grant for Down's Children Inc. earlier this year, that organisation has run into difficulties because it has not received expected assistance from the South Australian Government? Is the Minister aware that this is an extremely important program? Can he undertake to investigate the possibility of further funding?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Elstob said, Down's Children Inc. in South Australia, which cares for children with Down's syndrome, in fact has run into difficulties . I have had representations from various South Australian members and senators over this matter. In fact the organisation itself contacted me, as did the South Australian Government which supports the program but which cannot give any financial aid because of its commitments this year.

ANSWER.PARA: As a result of such submissions I have agreed to provide further funds of $12, 500 to meet a deficit incurred in 1983 and to an increase of $10,980 in the level of grant in 1983-84 to the organisation.

There will be a continuing discussion between the Office of Child Care in my Department and the Commonwealth Schools Commission as to the appropriate funding of such early intervention scheme projects which do not clearly fall within the responsibility of one department or another. However, the Government is committed to maintaining important projects like this, subject, of course, to the usual fiscal accountability and the economic availability of funds.

Therefore, at least at the moment Down's Children Inc. is covered. I am sure that as a result of discussions between me, my Department, the Schools Commission and the South Australian Government, all of which are very supportive in this area, this important organisation will be able to continue.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question to the Minister for Social Security refers to the handicapped child's allowance. Is the Minister aware that host families in Toowoomba, Queensland, who look after children from isolated areas who have hearing impairments and who are attending the special education unit at Wilsonton State School had been advised by the Department of Social Security that they could apply for the handicapped child's allowance? Is he further aware that when they did apply, their claims were subsequently rejected? Can the Minister offer any comment on that case? Can he also advise what assistance is available to those host families who may incur considerable costs in caring for children in those circumstances?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Messner raises an important matter which has been brought to my attention by the Special Education Unit in Toowoomba at, I think, the Wilsonton State School, and, in fact, by the host parents who are involved in this area. A small number of deaf childen from isolated areas in Queensland live with host families in Toowoomba so that they can attend the special units that are available at this school. I believe that it is an important and useful scheme. Host parents sign an agreement with the Queensland Minister for Education to provide accommodation and care for the children. They are paid an allowance for caring for the children in accordance with a scale which the Queensland Government's Education Department has established in consultation with those parents.

ANSWER.PARA: The difficulty is that the natural parents retain legal custody, care and control of the children while the children live with the host parents. Accordingly, the natural families continue to receive the family allowance. In general, they retain responsibility for most of the children's expenses, although I am informed by the organisation representing the host parents that, of course, some people-frequently because they are unable to do so-cannot contribute as much as perhaps they could or should to their children's expenses. Difficulty arises out of this situation because the host parents do not qualify for the handicapped child's allowance for these children because they do not have custody, care and control of the children. They therefore do not receive the family allowance; they are ineligible. I think everyone accepts that this is an unsatisfactory situation.

Many of the aspects of the handicapped child's allowance and its interrelationship with the family allowance are at the moment under examination. This matter has been referred to the Social Security Handicapped Persons Review Team which at the moment is looking at provisions of services for handicapped children generally, but in particular, I think that we always run into problems when we try to define eligibility in this area, particularly when we tie eligibility for one benefit to eligibility for another benefit, as happens here. I can assure Senator Messner that I do not see the situation as being satisfactory. It certainly was not anticipated by any previous government in its administration of the handicapped child's allowance. I hope that we can come up with a satisfactory answer in this regard as soon as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Finance aware of continuing concern within the tyre industry about sales tax on retread tyres? Originally it was forecast that, for example, in the case of a retread steel radial tyre for a Ford Falcon, the typical net addition to the wholesale price of $25 would be about $3.60. Already representation has been made to me by employers, the Federated Rubber and Allied Workers Union of Australia and the Truck Owners and Operators Association. I understand that the Government has been monitoring the situation. I ask the Minister whether there is any evidence of loss of employment, excessive cost to the industry or threat to road safety?

—I hope the Government has been monitoring the industry as well as Senator Hearn clearly has. I am fully aware of the complaints which have been made in the past. I have had complaints from employer organisations and the Federated Rubber and Allied Workers Union. I will make inquiries of the Minister for Finance and give Senator Hearn an answer about the monitoring process and its consequences as quickly as possible.

—I refer the Minister for Social Security to the effect of the proposed pensioner assets test on the owners of small properties adjoining urban areas. Has the Government considered whether the 10 per cent value assets criterion will disadvantage owners of small farming properties which adjoin urban areas and have a much higher value than like properties elsewhere? Has the Government reached a decision in respect of people in this situation who wish to retire?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In any assets test, one must of course take into account the special situation of rural dwellers, particularly rural dwellers who have been on farms for a lot of their lives. At the same time, one must take into account the fact that if a person has a very valuable and easily realisable asset, one must weigh his wanting to stay on the farm against the community's obligation to pay, for instance, as happens in some cases, full pensions and full fringe benefits to someone who owns a very valuable and easily realisable asset. We have built into the legislation and its regulations hardship provisions which take the situation of rural people into account. For instance, it would be clearly inequitable, and it is not intended, to insist on taking into account the full value of a farm during times of drought or rural recession when a person could not sell his property.

ANSWER.PARA: The same hardship provisions will be considered in regard to other properties which may not be easily realisable and it may be difficult to value. In the case of rural properties which abut not only on urban areas but also on holiday areas , such as areas of the south coast, several factors will be taken into account. Firstly, the home and an area called curtilage will be exempt. The size of that curtilage will partly depend on the amount of land which can be subdivided. Secondly, the amount of time a person spends on a farm and the amount of time he has been living there will be taken into account. Thirdly, it is quite clear that, particularly in areas close to an urban area, the value of the land may be some millions of dollars. I came across an example of that the other day. Those millions of dollars may be easily realisable. Excluding the house and reasonable curtilage, there may be land which, if sold, would realise an enormous amount. Under those circumstances, I think that everyone in this place should have to consider whether it is justifiable that the taxpayer should have to pay someone a full pension if that person has easily realisable assets. The position of rural people is, and always was, a special case. It was so under the previous assets test which was administered by conservative governments for so long. I am sure that, when Senator Walters and rural representatives see the legislation and the regulations, they will agree that we have come to a reasonable compromise in this situation. If they do not, we are certainly open to suggestions on how a compromise can be reached.

TALK.START.PARA: —During Question Time Senator Chipp asked me a question about weapons systems in space. I am able to give him at least this much of an answer at this stage. The Government is aware that various estimates have been made of the cost of establishing a satellite-based weapons system. It is generally agreed that any such system would be extremely expensive. The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) said in his speech to the United Nations General Assembly on 4 October that Australia will seek with all possible vigour an international agreement to ensure that the arms race does not extend to outer space. The content of confidential consultations with other countries has to remain confidential. Honourable senators may be assured, however, that the Government's views are conveyed whenever appropriate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 17 November 1983.
House of Representatives message-
Schedule of the amendment made by the Senate to which the House of Representatives has disagreed.
Page 4, clause 11, paragraph (a), after proposed new sub-section 14 (1), insert the following new sub-section:

'' '(1A) Where a person who is a non-citizen has either before or after the commencement of this sub-section been convicted of trafficking in dangerous drugs, or has been convicted in Australia of an offence and sentenced to imprisonment for a period of not less than five years, the Minister may, subject to this section, order the deportation of the person.'.''.
Reasons of the House of Representatives for disagreeing to the amendment of the Senate
The Senate amendment is not acceptable because-
(1) it is contrary to Government policy which is to create a statutory residential liability period beyond which non-citizens would not be deported unless convicted of security offences;
(2) it creates 2 new sub-classes of non-citizens liable to criminal deportation regardless of the length of their residence and unrelated to convictions on security grounds;
(3) it is badly worded, in that there is no definition of ''trafficking in dangerous drugs'', and

(4) the differences in proscription and sentencing amongst the State and Territory laws, particularly for serious offences, would make the application of the proposed provision inequitable, inconsistent and uneven in operation.
Motion (by Senator Grimes) proposed:
That the Committee does not insist on the amendment of the Senate to which the House of Representatives has disagreed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will not be insisting on the amendment moved and carried at the Committee stage when the Migration Amendment Bill was last debated here. However, when the Committee reports to the Senate I shall be moving an amendment which will indicate the Senate's opinion of this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Opposition and Senator Martin. I make it clear that we are aware that this Bill, once it is passed, will need further scrutiny, particularly with regard to sections 78 and 81 of the Crimes Act. The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West) has agreed to do that in conjunction with a consideration of the report of the Human Right Commission. I have moved the motion with that proviso.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Resolution reported.
Adoption of Report
Motion (by Senator Grimes) proposed:
That the report be adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add ', but the Senate-

(a) is of the opinion that the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs should move speedily to introduce further amendments to the Migration Act to include references to sections 28, 29 and 30 of the Crimes Act 1914 as grounds for deportation; and

(b) in view of the Minister's undertaking in the House of Representatives to ' consider including espionage related crimes as grounds for permanent deportation ', draws to the attention of the Government the urgent necessity to introduce further amendments to the Migration Act to include references to section 78 of the Crimes Act, relating to espionage and similar activities, and section 81 of that Act, relating to harbouring spies, so that the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs will have power to protect the people of Australia against persons who engage in these activities'.

When the Senate previously debated the Migration Amendment Bill on 2 November, in the Committee stage I moved an amendment to the Bill that certain other things become grounds for deportation. There was some misrepresentation, or maybe, at least, a pretty abysmal misunderstanding of the Opposition's attitude towards the Bill when it moved that amendment. I seek the Committee's indulgence for just a few minutes to state briefly what our amendment is about and what it is not about. We are not holding up passage of the Bill. We accept that the Bill needs to be passed. We disagree with some of the details of it and take this opportunity to emphasise the Senate's opinion.

The Migration Amendment Bill is essentially about two things. First, it removes the distinction which has existed, until this Bill receives assent, between aliens and immigrants in relation to entry and deportation controls. On that point, the Opposition has had no argument at any stage when it has debated the Bill, either previously in this chamber, or on the two occasions it was debated in the House of Representatives. The second part of the Bill outlines the bases for deportation of non-citizens, as these people will now be called. On the one hand, it outlines the basis of deportation for non-citizens with fewer than 10 years residence and on the other, outlines a very much narrower category of bases for deportation of non-citizens with more than 10 years residence. The only dispute has been on the last point-the basis for deportation of non- citizens who have more than 10 years residence in Australia.

There are in the Bill, as the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West) described them, security related grounds for deporting non-citizens who have had more than 10 years residence in Australia. A number of these are detailed in the Bill. Certain sections of the Crimes Act are referred to. These relate to crimes of inciting sedition, inciting mutiny, assisting prisoners of war to escape, unlawful drilling-that is, drilling of armies-being an accessory to any of these offences, attempting any of those offences or conspiring in relation to any of those offences. All those things are contained in the Bill. However, certain other offences against the Commonwealth were left out. One cannot help but feel that at least part of the omission was a drafting error. Our amendment would add section 28 of the Crimes Act to the Bill. It states:

Any person who, by violence or by threats or intimidation of any kind, hinders or interferes with the free exercise or performance, by any other person, of any political right or duty, shall be guilty of an offence.

That is referred to in the Crimes Act as interfering with political liberty. We consider that to be a serious crime. I emphasise that in expressing the opinion that these offences ought remain as part of the grounds for deportation. We are not saying that people ought to be automatically deported; not at all. We are saying that these are the sorts of crimes in relation to which we believe, if a person offends against then, the Minister ought to have the right to deport. Section 29 of the Crimes Act refers to destroying or damaging Commonwealth property and section 30 refers to seizing goods in Commonwealth custody.

The shadow Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Mr Hodgman, in debate in the House of Representatives, outlined in detail the sorts of incidents that are covered by those sections and the reasons that we believe they should be included. The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, in reply, detailed certain circumstances where it would be quite iniquitous, in his opinion, to deport. I emphasise that there was no quarrel at all with the sort of details that he gave where it would be iniquitous to deport. We seek to make the point that there are certain offences for which, when committed, the Minister ought to have the right to deport non-citizens.

The most serious sections of the Crimes Act are sections 78 and 81 which are included in the second part of our amendment. Whilst, as I have said, the Government includes as grounds for deportation after 10 years residence such matters as inciting mutiny and of assisting prisoners of war to escape it has not kept for itself the right to deport someone who is convicted of spying or of harbouring spies. One is tempted to think that this was a drafting error. Most of the offences that are included in the Migration Amendment Bill come from a part of the Crimes Act which gathers together under a general heading things described as 'Offences against the Government'. The offences, included in the first part of the amendment we have moved, ought also to be included under that heading. The offences that the Government has included in the Migration Amendment Bill appear under that heading.

Further on in the Crimes Act is a special part called 'Espionage and Official Secrets'. It is here that section 78 relating to espionage and section 81 relating to harbouring spies are contained. One is tempted to think that the draftsman did not turn enough pages in the Bill, in which case I think it is a pity that the Government has not moved a little faster in at least rectifying this defect, the inclusion of the spying and harbouring of spies sections of the Crimes Act. The House of Representatives debated this Bill on 24 August. In that debate the shadow Minister for Immigration (Mr Hodgman) and other Opposition speakers pointed out this defect. The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs brushed aside those criticisms at the time and talked instead about those clauses of the Bill with which there is no argument.

The Senate debated this Bill first on 2 November and forced an amendment. At that point the Minister was obliged to take notice of what was said. The amendment was notified and debated in the House of Representatives on 16 November. Then the Minister gave grounds for rejecting the amendment that had been previously carried by the Senate. Part of his grounds was technical. He said that the amendment could not be accepted as an amendment to the Bill in the form in which it then was. The Bill is now back before the Senate for final consideration on 2 December. In that whole period this very obvious defect in relation to the option of deportation of someone who spies or harbours spies has still not been acted on. It has been pointed out and I point it out again that there is no reason why the Government, if it did not consider this an important defect, could not have acted by now by bringing in a minor amending Bill including those sections of the Crimes Act. I ask the Government: Why not bring in this amendment?

The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs in debate in the House of Representatives and the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) who represents him in the Senate have said that they are aware that the Bill needs further examination but they are waiting on the report from the Human Rights Commission before they do anything. As far as I am aware, there is no indication where this report will come in. The Human Rights Commission is still receiving evidence, I believe, in its investigation into this matter. In the meantime, we are unprotected. I do not want to be unduly melodramatic. Some people are given to melodrama on this subject but one never knows what will appear in the newspaper the next day. Two days ago who would have dreamt that there would have been men with sub-machine guns rushing around the foyer of a prestigious hotel? We do not know these things are going on. It is only when something extraordinary like that happens-

TALK.START.PARA: —Why did you say men? Why did you not say 'persons'?
—I do not believe in neutering people.
—Women can do that too.

—If they had I would have said men and women. I was referring to a specific episode. We do not know, and nobody can shrug his shoulders and say it will not happen now and again. A couple of things ought to be borne in mind. Some of the most celebrated espionage cases in modern history have involved people who were long term residents of countries but who were not citizens. The Rosenbergs were not American citizens; there is some dispute as to whether Lord Haw-Haw should have been executed for treason, because he was not a British citizen. It has been disputed, therefore, whether he had in fact committed treason.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is we are talking about people in a very particular position who are not citizens of this country but who are long term residents. I suggest there is in modern history good evidence that foreign agents often are long term residents of the country against which they are working. Every country should have the right to protect itself. To cut off arbitrarily after 10 years residence and say: 'Past that point, we do not want the option of deportation' is not a reasonable view or a well founded view. I reiterate: We are not suggesting automatic deportation but we are saying there is an important case for having the option of deportation in the case of spies and people who harbour spies.

If the Government is determined not to move on these two matters until the Human Rights Commission report is in, I ask why it moved at all before receiving that report if that is now so significant. The Government probably could have looked at how it could have amended the Migration Act to remove that distinction between aliens and immigrants-as they were previously referred to in the Act- without touching at this stage the bases for deportation, if it was still up in the air as to whether the Human Rights Commission report which might give superior information to that on which it has based this amending Bill. So I reiterate to the Government that the Opposition is concerned about the fact that there will be an important gap in this legislation until such time as the Government brings in the amendment to include at least the offences of espionage and harbouring spies.

Whilst we accept that the Minister has indicated that he acknowledges these omissions, I suggest there was a fair amount of double talk in the debate on this particular point in the House of Representatives and we seek this opportunity to urge the Minister, as a matter of urgency, to look at further amendments to the Migration Act to include references to espionage and harbouring spies. We say in our amendment that that is urgent. The other part of the amendment indicates that other amendments should be brought in to the Bill to include other sections of that part of the Crimes Act referred to as offences against the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I make some comments on this amendment to the motion that the report of the Committee of the Whole be adopted . I am glad that the Senate is not insisting on the amendment to the Migration Amendment Bill that was carried some little time ago. I expressed then great doubts about the fuzziness of the expression of the amendment and about the question whether these particular examples should be picked out for resurrecting discretion for the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs over deportation. I am glad that we are not insisting at this stage on the amendment carried at the Committee stage.

SPEECH.PARA: I must say at this report stage that I have some reservations about another part of the amendment, too. In regard to part (b) of the amendment, the reference to sections 78 and 81 of the Crimes Act, there is validity for expressing the idea that they should be attended to and should be included. I remind the Senate that the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West) , on 16 November 1983 when debating the Senate's amendment had this to say:
Why include all those sections--
that is, the earlier sections included in the Crimes Act-

of the Crimes Act and leave out sections 78 and 81 which relate to espionage offences? I simply express surprise that seeing Opposition senators had the numbers during the debate, and if they felt this matter was important, they did not send it here as an amendment. I would have been inclined to accept it if they had, but they did not; they left it out.

Irrespective of whose job it was to prepare the Bill and to propose matters and amendments, surely it is clear that the Minister recognises that there is certain validity in this matter being considered and, as Senator Martin said, being considered fairly urgently.

I express some reservations in regard to part (a) of the amendment if it were to be read literally. It wants the consideration of sections 'to include references to sections 28, 29 and 30 of the Crimes Act 1914 as grounds for deportation'. I have many reservations about certain provisions of the Crimes Act. It seems to me that the Crimes Act is in need of very urgent reconsideration in many ways. Much of it has been put together in a patchwork way over the years. Much of it represents certain illiberal eras in our history. I am not sure that there are not some unwise provisions in that Act. Perhaps they are mitigated by the sense which governments have to not prosecute on literal offences under the sections. But the three offences that Senator Martin suggested should be included are all offences against the Government. One wonders why offences against the Government would necessarily have greater importance-giving the Minister that wide discretion to deport, which many have found unsatisfactory in the past-just because they are offences against the Government. Surely there must be some better rationale for any decision to resurrect the ministerial discretion in this area. I certainly think they should be considered and where they are serious infringements, perhaps that is a proper ground. For example, if we take the three offences that were mentioned, one refers to interference with any political right. That can be very important. But it could refer to a drunk outside a polling booth who punches the nose of someone who is going in to vote, so that that person is carted off to hospital and cannot vote.

TALK.START.PARA: —You do not seriously suggest deportation, do you?

—I would have felt that the honourable senator's interjection would be that surely the Minister, using his discretion, would not deport in that case. I recognise that the point I am making is answerable on that ground. But the senator suggests giving into his hands an area which may be minor, may be on the borderline, or may be major. It may be the case that references to those sections ought to deal with important infringements that show that the person is not fit to be a citizen of or to live in this country. The same thing could be said in regard to the destruction of Commonwealth property-it could be minor or major-and the seizing of property. All offences that might happen under those sections ought not necessarily be ones that resurrect the Minister's right to remove someone who has been in this country for 10 years.
—That would be true also of section 81.

—Yes. I think the whole question ought to be looked at. I am glad that the Human Rights Commission is looking at these matters. The mere fact of a conviction against a particular section might not in itself be adequate. That was the problem in regard to the amendment which we moved in relation to trafficking in dangerous drugs. The point I raised then was that the crime of trafficking in dangerous drugs could be minor or major. I raise this question as being a consideration that should be looked at. I hope the Human Rights Commission will look at whether references to these sections should be in relation to convictions of an important nature.

SPEECH.PARA: I mention also that the Minister referred in the debate on the Senate's amendment to the criticisms made by the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. I hope that a number of those criticims will be considered during the preparation of a new Bill which obviously will have to follow the whole consideration of the question by the Human Rights Commission. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

DEBATE.TITLE: STATES GRANTS (EDUCATION ASSISTANCE-PARTICIPATION AND EQUITY) BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: [COGNATE BILLS:
STATES GRANTS (SCHOOLS ASSISTANCE) BILL 1983
STATES GRANTS (TERTIARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1983]
Debate resumed from 30 November 1983, on motion by Senator Gietzelt:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the absence of the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) I suggest that the States Grants ( Education Assistance-Participation and Equity) Bill, the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Bill 1983 and the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill 1983 be debated cognately, although separate questions will be put on each Bill.
—Is it the wish of the Senate to have a general debate covering the three Bills? I will allow that course to be followed.

—Thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President. Together these three education Bills represent a package of legislation which gives effect to the education funding guidelines announced by the Minister in July last. With other measures announced in the Budget, they represent the Government financial proposals for education during calendar year 1984. While not opposing the passage of the Bills, the Opposition will be moving amendments both at the second reading stage of two of the Bills and in Committee. For the purposes of discussion, I indicate that at an appropriate time the Opposition will be moving an amendment to the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add ', but the Senate condemns the Government for its many dishonoured promises to Australian tertiary students'.
To the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Bill at the end of the second reading, the Opposition will move:
At end of motion, add ', but the Senate-
(a) condemns the Government for its many dishonoured promises to Australian secondary students;
(b) calls for the restoration of the right of all children to receive guaranteed Government support for their education;
(c) insists on the right of every Australian child to receive support for his or her schooling at a level which is predictable and related to educational costs in Government schools;
(d) supports the principle of freedom of choice in education and the right of all parents to be supported in that choice;
(e) deplores the restriction on the free development of non-Government schools as an expression of the will of parents; and
(f) condemns the Government for the unexplained and arbitrary cuts to some Schools Commission Programs and, in particular, to the Professional Development Program'.

I will move the amendments at the appropriate stage. They reflect the clear rejection by the Opposition of some aspects of the Labor Government's education program. They reflect our concern, and the concern of many in the education community about the many dishonoured election commitments and assurances which have been part of this Government's sorry performance in the short time it has been in office. The Minister in her first education program has presided over a situation where education spending, as a proportion of total outlays, has fallen by 0.3 per cent. While the amounts involved may have gone up, the share of total outlays which education has been able to claim has, in fact, fallen. The action of this Government has not matched the rhetoric with which it went to the people . Nowhere is this more evident than in higher education. The Opposition acknowledges that some extra funding is being provided for tertiary education but we note particularly the disappointment expressed by those in the tertiary education sector about the guidelines laid down in that area. The tertiary education assistance legislation contains very little that is new or innovative. What we do see is a reduction of one quarter in the subsidy paid to collegiate residences at universities and colleges of advanced education, being done in advance of a review which the Minister tells us is now being carried out. Why cut funding ahead of the review taking place; why move in and cut funds before the Government has received advice about whether that is necessary? In addition, we have seen the proposal to insert a new section which introduces as a condition of grant equal opportunity provisions. We have no objection to that. However we think, and the advice we have received is, that given the performance of tertiary education in recent years this provision is likely to be more symbolic and indicative of a desire for certain outcomes than prescriptive of certain action.

I wish to comment on another aspect of the tertiary education guidelines, the provision of a little more than $10m with which to establish, according to the Minister, 3,000 new places. If we consider the number of places provided in higher education and the amount of money that is being spent in that regard, we find that the cost of one student place is approximately $6,000. The amount per student place that is being provided under these guidelines represents only half of that figure. The Minister may argue that only a marginal cost is involved but the amount provided allows for nothing like the sum that is now being spent, on the average, in the provision of a student place. The tertiary sector, the Higher Education Round Table and organisations representing staff, have been quick to pick this up, quick to criticise the Government for requiring the provision of 3,000 extra places from what they consider to be inadequate funding , inadequate provision and inadequate support. We are going to see that, despite the increase in funding in 1984, the requirement for extra places will mean a reduction in the real level of spending per student in higher education across Australia. So it is not surprising that we see in the report that came down recently from the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission criticism of the Government for its lack of adequate long term planning, its lack of assurances as to long term funding and its failure to provide for capital expenditure with which to maintain the 3,000 extra places that are to be provided.

The Minister has gone further and has attempted to identify who will fill some of these places. She has said that the places are to be used to widen access for disadvantaged groups. The Opposition would want an assurance from the Minister that this will not imply any fall in educational standards, that those who occupy these places from disadvantaged groups will be qualified for entry, and that the extra places will be used to meet demand where it exists now. We do not want to see an instruction that the disadvantaged be taken in. We do not want to see any situation where they are taken in at entry requirements which differ from those for the majority of students and we do not want to see a situation where the existing unmet demand cannot be reduced because some of the places have been spoken for in advance.

The Minister's concern to encourage participation and to widen access for disadvantaged groups has to be seen against the background of some of the other actions of this Government in funding, in the guidelines and in the Budget. It has to be seen against the failure to increase assistance for tertiary students in real terms. Tertiary students in this country are behind in real terms. The amount given to them by way of the tertiary education assistance allowance will not keep up with inflation so they are worse off. The Minister's concern also has to be seen against the fact that the means test, under which TEAS is governed, did not increase sufficiently to allow the same number of people to enter so that the eligibility has diminished just by a small amount.

There were election promises to the contrary. There were election promises about the level of TEAS which have not been kept. Labor promised progressively to increase student assistance through TEAS until it equalled the single unemployment benefit. It promised then to maintain the nexus. That has not been done. Labor promised to raise the TEAS means test until it equated average weekly earnings. That has not been done. Until it--

TALK.START.PARA: —Average weekly earnings? No, try again.

—The Minister promised to increase the means test and she has not done it. The gap between the TEAS benefit and the unemployment benefit has widened, with unemployment and the unemployment benefit being more attractive options for young people now than they were when Senator Ryan took over as Minister for Education and Youth Affairs. The promise was that this Government would make education more attractive. The reality is that it has totally failed and it has widened the gap. The proportion of students actually receiving TEAS at the end of 1984 will drop because the number of extra enrolments in higher education will be greater than the number of people getting more student assistance.

SPEECH.PARA: By abolishing the previous Government's student loan scheme-which it was entitled to do-but then failing to put in place, or to honour its commitment to put in place, an emergency loans scheme, the Government has removed a benefit which was available to students as a possible source of finance. It has not replaced it with anything in spite of promises to the contrary-another promise given and another promise broken.

I note the recent call by the Australian and New Zealand Student Services Association for an expansion of campus-based emergency loans schemes and the claims that it made that campuses are unable to cope with demand for emergency loans assistance. There is another decision which would seem to be a clear contradiction of the Labor Government's professed concern for the disadvantaged. That is a reduction by 25 per cent in the subsidy paid to residential colleges. This is likely in the necessity for some of the colleges to raise their fees for students, perhaps by $2 a week. Taken alongside the failure to maintain TEAS in real terms, this will further add to the hardship of many students. I remind the Minister that many of these students are country students for whom college is one of the few options open to them. As just one example of the ad hoc way in which decisions are being taken by this Government, this reduction will occur in 1984 with the whole matter pending a review by the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission. If the Government is going to proceed I suggest that the way to proceed is to get its advice first and then to make the decision on the basis of that advice, and not do it back to front as it has done.

The Minister in her guidelines and in her Press releases has talked about access for disadvantaged groups, but we can see little of any specific nature to tell us how this access to disadvantaged groups will be provided. The Minister has talked particularly about women and Aboriginals. I might say that if one looks at the figures for higher education in the last few years one finds that the enrolments of women have increased rapidly and any disadvantage now is only in certain faculties where the gender difference favours males, perhaps in faculties such as engineering. Equally, I hope that the Minister would want to see in those faculties in which women predominate that males are encouraged to enrol and that gender differences there are overcome-unless, of course, her definition of 'disadvantaged' applies only to one sex.

The Labor Government has failed students and it has failed the higher education community in its first Budget and its first guidelines. At a time when we need an increasing amount of higher education and skills the Government is asking students to accept less personal support and to bear the brunt of economic difficulties. The hollow commitment to improving educational participation is illustrated quite well in the new Bill, the States Grants (Education Assistance- Participation and Equity) Bill. The Minister has described this participation and equity program as the centrepiece of the Government's youth programs. What it actually is is the school to work transition program with $20m thrown in. For that $20m everyone should be grateful, and I salute the Government for the provision of that money. I acknowledge that that is a useful extra provision of support. If it can encourage participation that is excellent, but what has happened is that the participation and equity program has been swallowed up.

During the Estimates Committee examination of these matters I asked the Minister what would happen, whether there would be projects under the school to work transition program that would not be suitable for funding under the new program. Any honourable senators interested in this matter should read the Hansard record of that exchange. It was impossible to get from the Minister an indication of a single project under the school to work transition program that would not be suitable for funding. That suggests that the likelihood is that the school to work transition program will continue to be funded, perhaps projects will change marginally to meet the new guidelines, and that what will go in as extra will be that very desirable $20m.

What worries us is that the call for participation is really a fairly hollow call. It is generally acknowledged that if educational participation rates are to rise two matters must be addressed. The first is the perversities in the current structure of income support for youth which continue to make unemployment the best paid option. It is clearly absurd that a young person looking at economics should say: 'I am better off on the dole and I am worse off in education'. The Government has failed to address and to redress that situation. Secondly, it is essential that educational offerings are improved so that further study may come to be regarded as valuable and worth while. Participation in education is not an educational purpose in itself. Participation as a strategy in isolation is meaningless. Participation will be relevant and valuable only to the extent that the educational offerings are themselves relevant and valued. They are not so valued today. Greater participation is therefore a limited prescription and a flawed goal in advance of qualitative reassessment and qualitative renewal of what education offers its consumers. Much of what it offers is pretty poor.

Let us not forget that the Commission of Inquiry into Poverty wrote in the mid- 1970s of the deep alienation of school leavers and of their strong negative feelings about schooling, that the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission in its report 'Learning and Earning' commented on the active dislike many young people have for the education system, and that most recently the Beswick report commented on the negative incentive value of much educational experience at both the secondary and tertiary levels. I say to the Minister: We wish this program well. We have yet to see that it is going to be more than tokenism, but we hope the extra $20m will be well spent and we will be looking carefully to see what comes out of it.

I now wish to concentrate my remarks on the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Bill because it is in this Bill that the Government and the Minister have revealed their true colours. The Bill exposes Labor's true aspirations for Australian schooling. But the Bill does more than that because it identifies further the extent to which another series of promises made before the election have been abandoned or broken. I will just run through some of the promises: The promise to institute a new program for primary schools at a level of $9m per annum, not honoured; the promise to provide an additional $37m in the first year of the Government for recurrent resources in Government schools, not honoured; the promise to provide an additional $16m in the first year of the program for needy non-government schools, not honoured; the promise to provide $24m over three years for computer education, only a smaller amount was honoured; the promise to establish a revolving loan fund with an initial contribution of $5m to bring forward construction planned for new non-government schools, not honoured, and so it goes in terms of promises not kept.

As long as the Government and the Minister pursue the course they have chosen to take, as long as the Minister believes that the purpose of education is to advance the Government's social and philosophical goals rather than its educational goals, there will not be any bipartisanship in her approaches to education as they apply to schooling. This legislation embodies perhaps the most destructive and the most discriminatory proposals for education which we have seen before the Senate. This legislation gives effect to the Hawke Government's decision to abandon the percentage link for funding non-government schools; that is the nexus which has linked the cost of educating a child in a government school with a grant paid to children in non-government schools. That is a formula which gave certainty to non-government schools which they regard as the very basis of their continued support.

This Bill abolishes the basic right to a grant for every Australian child through action which has been taken to penalise a few children in a few schools. Non-government schools exist only because some people want an alternative for their children. We believe in a dual system. We believe in choice and we believe in diversity. Whilever there is too little choice within government schools for parents there will be a need for them to have some alternative way of exercising a choice. If the Minister would care to take upon herself the task of increasing choice as between and within government schools, she would go a long way to helping advance our emphasis upon choice and upon diversity. But the dual system is valued because people want choice and they want diversity, and it is valued because some people see within the alternative system an ethos, a sense of discipline, a sense of purpose, a sense of mission which they think is valuable for their children and because many of them have disquiet about the activities of the teachers unions.

Many parents see educators as trustees on behalf of their children. They do not see them as chosen or self-appointed agents of social change. I reiterate that one of the reasons-just one amongst many-that parents want to have non- government schools available across Australia in increasing numbers, is because they believe that their children are being indoctrinated with values which they do not share and which they are determined to reject. Many parents sheet these unacceptable values home to the teachers federations and to those who would use the education system for the achievement of a union's or a government's ideological goals. For those parents, non-government schools are the only available exit route.

This Bill does several undesirable things: It reduces funding in 1984 over what would have been available under the previous formula for 120,000 children in group 1 schools across Australia. They will all get less. It markedly penalises 41 schools which are on this arbitrary hit list. It abolishes the formula determining predictable grants under a percentage link and a funding nexus. The Bill puts enormous new obstacles in the way of new or expanded non-government schools across Australia. The fallacy which is ignored by the Australian Labor Party is that non-government schools in Australia will prosper and can prosper only if parents are willing to support them and to pay money from their own after-tax income for the privilege. It is the financial support of parents that makes non-government schools viable. The Government's measures will not hurt schools as much as they will hurt parents. If the funding cuts mean that fees have to rise it is the parents who will have to pay them.

Whilever the ALP cannot understand that it is because parents make these schools succeed with their money, time and support we will continue to have this fallacy that in some way the schools get their funding out of thin air and are rich because they somehow inherited their money. The schools are well resourced only because parents make them well resourced out of their own pockets. We believe that that parental effort must be recognised. We cannot understand the formula which is coming up whereby schools will be eligible for a greater public subsidy if parents reduce their input and their support. What kind of situation is that? That is a poverty trap of the worst kind. The Government will say to parents: 'Pay less, reduce your fees, reduce your offerings and under the formula your school will be eligible for funding.' The parents are certain that Senator Susan Ryan fails to understand them, their aspirations and their hopes, and, in turn, they do not trust her. I remind her of the meetings that have been held. I remind her of the meeting of 5,000 parents. I remind her, much as she may not want to be reminded, that 280 schools were represented at that meeting and that 130 of those schools were group 3 Catholic schools. The parents of the children attending those schools attended the meeting to protest against what she and her Government are doing.

We have no doubt whatsoever that there is a hidden agenda. It may be a hidden agenda within the ALP but it is certainly an open agenda in terms of many of the ALP supporters. We can refer to what the teachers federations, including the New South Wales Teachers Federation, the Australian Teachers Federation and the Australian Council of State School Organisations have said. Their view is clear. They have some goals. Their goals are first, to contain the non-government system and prevent its expansion, secondly, to impoverish parts of the sector, to drive people out by economic deprivation; thirdly, to increase the amount of regulation and harassment within the sector; and, fourthly, to move steadily towards setting up an environment in which the integration of schools, in spite of the Government's assurances, becomes more likely. Interestingly, the Government can make integration more likely by taking over an increasing proportion of the funding. For example, I think the schools most dangerously facing integration today are group 3 schools, because as the amount of government funding goes up so does the amount of government control. I am attracted to some of the arguments that Senator Macklin put forward.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what the Sydney meeting was about. It passed a motion.

—Not with my support. I am attracted to some of Senator Macklin's speeches in which he has talked about increased public control. Senator Macklin has made it quite clear where he stands but the funding mechanisms coming in now make integration more likely. The Berlin Wall is offensive to many of us because that wall, between East and West Berlin, is evidence of a state trying to erect barriers to prevent the escape of those who wish to leave it. Senator Ryan's guidelines are a Berlin wall in education. They are seeking to make it harder for people to leave one system for another. Instead of seeking to restore confidence in the government system, instead of seeking to improve a situation where there will be freedom of choice within the government systems, she is trying to make it more difficult for people to exit to another system which they prefer. The move to limit expansion of schools is part of a Berlin wall in education. The move to reduce grants to all group 1 schools is part of a Berlin wall in education-a means to put a barrier in front of those who want to move from one system to another and exercise their choice. The failure to honour the promises it made in education, the promises it made to government and non-goverment schools, is again part of the Berlin wall approach. We have set out the promises; we know what they are.

SPEECH.PARA: Because my thinking is directed towards individuals, it follows that like political colleagues I value diversity in choice of education. I do not agree with those who value system efficiency or system needs over choice by individuals. I do not agree with those who assert that parents and children have less right to choose than do central planners. I do not agree with those who present education and its politics as part of a class struggle with policy based on perjorative assertions about certain advantaged institutions or groups. I assert that if one is going to extol education as enabling one-I quote Senator Ryan's words-'to resist manipulation by the massive institutions of capitalism', one should also extol it as enabling one to resist massive institutions of government and massive institutions of bureaucracy unless one is playing a crude and overtly political hand.

I do not believe that any policy directed at levelling down educational offerings has any community benefit at all to commend it. I believe what is being proposed here will make this more likely. I seek to reduce structural social disadvantage and I wholeheartedly support the goal of equality of opportunity in education. But the purpose of education is not, and never can be, an equality of educational outcomes.

The provisions in this Bill frighten parents, and so they should. I call on the Government to listen to opposition from so many quarters. I call on the Government to begin to honour many pre-election promises about due process and about the fair sharing of funds. I call on the Government to desist in 1984 from any action that would reduce grants further to the 41 schools or that would include new schools in the hit list or that would reduce further the position of thrifty parents who are contributing so much to education in Australia or which would make it more difficult for schools to be established or to expand. I support the Bills. I will move our amendments at the appropriate stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating cognately the States Grants (Education Assistance-Participation and Equity) Bill 1983, the States Grants ( Schools Assistance) Bill 1983 and the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill 1983. I wish to make a number of comments on all three Bills. Probably more detailed comments can be made on the clauses of these Bills during the Committee stage. I think it would be better to deal with the Bills in detail at that stage.

SPEECH.PARA: In general, I support the Staes Grants (Education Assistance-Participation and Equity) Bill 1983. The Australian Democrats welcome the initiatives taken by the Government in relation to this Bill. The objective, as stated by the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) during her second reading speech, of encouraging a significant increase of participation by young people in education and training, to provide a useful and fulfilling education and to encourage the achievements of more equal educational outcomes is a magnificent objective. Oh, that we could reach that! Unfortunately, this Bill falls short of this aim; but that is to be expected. Hopefully, over the years we will move in that direction and achieve more and more of those well worthwhile aims.

This Bill appears to be a major attempt to do something about the issues of equal opportunity that were raised in the fifth and main report of the Commission of Inquiry into Poverty entitled 'Poverty and Education in Australia' . Nevertheless, quite a number of items still concern us. For example, the Poverty Commission stressed in its report at the very outset that the unequal outcomes of schooling cannot be fixed by simply tinkering. I think that yet again we may have fallen for the educational equivalent of a three-card trick. The previous Government sought a way out, which was referred to by Senator Peter Baume, in terms of a variety of programs, the transition programs. I have spoken before in this chamber about those programs, most of which, I feel, were probably not worth the money spent on them. I am quite happy to say that. The alternative use of that money, I believe, could have achieved more in terms of equality of opportunity.

I believe that the major reason for our failure to solve our problems in this area is that we keep believing for some reason or another that educational disadvantage is an educational problem. Educational disadvantage is a social problem and will only eventually be solved by social policies, not by educational policies. A simple illustration of that would be two children sitting behind the same desk in a classroom anywhere in Australia. One of those children could be the child of a surgeon at a hospital; the child sitting next to him could be the child of a person who is unemployed. Regardless of the resources that we pour into the institution, the comparative educational opportunity of those children will never be changed. Essentially, the major contribution that is made in that classroom is made by the teacher. But the teacher can provide only roughly the same support to both of those children. Any other resources, whether they be library, audio-visual, science laboratories or whatever, again will provide only equal opportunities to each of those children. Yet each of those children approaches the educational task with quite unequal backgrounds in terms of the resources that their parents can supply. Until we tackle that social problem we will not affect in any material way the problem of equality of educational opportunity in this country.
The report of the Poverty Commission states:

Factors such as social class, sex, geographical location, ethnicity and age all play a part. Those who gain least from the schooling system tend to be at the bottom of the social scale where lack of post school qualifications perpetuates their position.
